sub_topic: Finding the velocity and acceleration of an object using calculus
message_1: A particle moves along the x-axis according to the equation x(t) = 3t² - 4t + 1, where t is measured in seconds and x is measured in meters. Find the velocity and acceleration of the particle at t = 2 seconds.
message_2:
To find the velocity and acceleration of the particle at t = 2 seconds, we first need to find the first and second derivatives of the position function x(t) with respect to time t.

The position function is given by:
x(t) = 3t² - 4t + 1

The first derivative of x(t) with respect to t will give us the velocity function v(t):
v(t) = dx/dt = d(3t² - 4t + 1)/dt = 6t - 4

Now, we can find the velocity at t = 2 seconds by substituting t = 2 into the velocity function:
v(2) = 6(2) - 4 = 12 - 4 = 8 m/s

Next, we need to find the second derivative of x(t) with respect to t, which will give us the acceleration function a(t):
a(t) = dv/dt = d(6t - 4)/dt = 6

Since the acceleration function is a constant, the acceleration at t = 2 seconds is the same as the acceleration at any other time:
a(2) = 6 m/s²

So, the velocity of the particle at t = 2 seconds is 8 m/s, and the acceleration is 6 m/s².
